Aminoacids are one of the most important classes of building blocks for proteins and peptides [1]. The twenty natural amino acids are widely distributed in food, condiments, pharmaceutical preparations, and even metabolites in the human body [2,3]. As a consequence, the development of reliable methods for amino acid recognition and determination are of great signi /uniFB01 cance in food testing, nutritional analysis, medical diagnostics, and for numerous other /uniFB01 elds [4 -9]. To date, many methods, including high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) [10], gas chromatography (GC) [11], capillary electrophoresis (CE) [12],and optical techniques [13,14], have been employed for the recognition and detection of the twenty natural amino acids. Among the optical techniques, the /uniFB02 uorescence approach is particular attractive given its excellent selectivity, fast response time, low detection limits, and the inexpensive instrumentation required [15]. Nevertheless, it remains a challenge to develop an effective /uniFB02 uorescent probe system for the detection of speci /uniFB01 c amino acids.
The synthetic macrocyclic receptors, cucurbit[ n ]urils (abbreviated as Q[ n ]s, Fig. 1) comprise n glycoluril units bridged by 2 n methylene groups [16 -21],and possess hydrophobic cavities and carbonyl-laced portals. Cucurbit[ n ]urils have been shown to bind organic guests in

In recent years, Q[ n ]s and derivatives thereof have been reported to encapsulate a number of speci /uniFB01 c amino acids, peptides and proteins [30 -39]. It is well recognized that the encapsulation or release of guests by hosts can bring about substantial alteration in the chemical and physical properties of the guests [40 -49]. For example, Chang and co-workers demonstrated that the /uniFB02 uorescence of palmatine (PAL) in aqueous solution was greatly enhanced when encapsulated by the cavity of Q[7] [50 -53]. The competitive reaction between target drugs and the PAL for the occupancy of Q[7] cavity can result in /uniFB02 uorescence quenching, and this can be utilized for the recognition of the different drugs. The studies of Chang prompted us to investigate whether the PAL probe could be encapsulated within the Q[7] cavity to form an inclusion complex, and then whether the Q[7]@PAL could be used to sense the binding of natural amino acids.
In the present work, we have studied the binding properties of Q[7] towards PAL using a number of techniques including 1 HNMRspectroscopy, UV -vis and /uniFB02 uorescence spectroscopy, and isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC), and found that a 1:1 host-guest inclusion complex is formed, which displayed /uniFB02 uorescence of moderate intensity. More importantly, when phenylalanine (Phe) was added to the 1:1 hostguest inclusion complex of Q[7]@PAL, the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity of the inclusion complex was dramatically quenched. However, the addition of any other natural amino acids to the same inclusion complex did not lead to any distinct /uniFB02 uorescence changes. These observations

Microcalorimetric experiments were performed using an isothermal titration calorimeter Nano ITC (TA, USA). The heat evolved was recorded at 298.15 K. Thebindingproperties of Q[7] towards PAL in aqueous solution have been monitored by 1 HNMRspectroscopic experiments. Fig. 2 shows the 1 H NMR spectra of PAL in the absence and in the presence of differing equivalents of Q[7] in neutral D2O solution. Upon the addition of increasing amounts of host Q[7], the Ha, Hb Hc, Hd and He protons of the PAL were shifted up /uniFB01 eld, whilst the Hf, Hi, Hj protons of the PAL were gradually shifted down /uniFB01 eld. This behavior can be rationalized by the inclusion of the methoxy-isoquinoline motif inside the cavity of the host, with the substituted benzene ring remaining outside.

The /uniFB02 uorescence spectroscopy of PAL also showed a large change upon the addition of Q[7]. It is well known that PAL display no intrinsic /uniFB02 uorescence in aqueous solution [54], however, upon the gradual addition of Q[7] the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity of PAL displays a signi /uniFB01 cant enhancement. This observed enhancement is attributed to the formation of a 1:1 host-guest inclusion complex in which the Q[7] host provides a hydrophobic microenvironment for the guest [55,56].

To further understand the nature of the host -guest complexation of Q[7] with PAL, isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) experiments (Fig. 6) were carried out. The ITC data revealed that the host -guest complexation is both enthalpically and entropically favorable ( Δ H ° = -29.14 kJ·mol -1 , T Δ S ° = 5.40 kJ·mol -1 , Δ G ° = -34.54 kJ·mol -1 ). As mentioned above, PAL does not display native /uniFB02 uorescence in aqueous solution. Whereas when PAL was encapsulated into the Q[7]
cavity, the resulting inclusion complex emits /uniFB02 uorescence of moderate intensity. To ascertain whether this inclusion complex PAL@Q[7] can be used to recognize natural amino acids, we carried out a series of /uniFB02 uorescence measurements. Interestingly, when Phe (1 × 10 -4 mol·L -1 ) was added to the 1:1 inclusion complex of Q[7] (2 × 10 -5 mol·L -1 ) with PAL (2 × 10 -5 mol·L -1 ), the /uniFB02 uorescence characteristic of the inclusion complex PAL@Q[7] showed dramatic changes, and /uniFB02 uorescence quenching was observed. However, the addition of any of the other 19 natural amino acids (1 × 10 -4 mol·L -1 ) failed to afford any distinct changes in the /uniFB02 uorescence(Fig. 7). These observations suggest that the inclusion complex PAL@Q[7] can be used for the selective recognition of the Phe in aqueous solution.

The effect of varying the Phe concentration on the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity of the Q[7]/PAL complex was also investigated. The concentrations of Phe were varied from 0 to 10 × 10 -5 mol·L -1 , and the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity of the Q[7]/PAL complex was found to gradually increase as the Phe concentration increased (Fig. 8). It is worth mentioning that the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity (F) exhibited a near linear relationship with the Phe concentration over a certain range of concentrations (from 0 to 2.0 × 10 -5 mol·L -1 ). The linear range was 0 -2 × 10 -5 mol·L -1 . and the linear regression equations were F = 12.4091C + 86.6569 (C denotes the concentration (mol·L -1 ) of Phe) with correlation coef /uniFB01 cients of 0.9908, which indicated near linearity.

To understand the response mechanism of the /uniFB02 uorescence quenching of Q[7]/PAL on addition of Phe, we monitored the 1 H NMR spectra of Phe when combined with the Q[7]/PAL inclusion complex. The results revealed that all the peaks of the protons associated with the Phe were shifted to higher /uniFB01 eld relative to those of free Phe. This indicated that the Phe was located inside the Q[7] cavity (Fig. 9), whilst the movement down /uniFB01 eld and broadening of the protons associated with PAL was consistent one included PAL molecule being replaced the Phe molecule, thereby forming a 1:1 inclusion complex.
It has been documented that the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity associated with PAL can be greatly enhanced when it included in the hydrophobic cavity of Q[7] [41 -43]. When the PAL was encapsulated into the Q[7] cavity, the isoquinoline ring and the substituted benzene ring forms an effective conjugated system, which leads to enhancement of the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity. An additional factor favorable for /uniFB02 uorescence enhancement is that the degree of freedom of motion of the PAL molecule in the Q[7] cavity is reduced, thereby reducing the probability of radiationless transition. At the same time, the cavity can shield the excited singlet state of PAL from typical quenching processes that usually occur in an aqueous solution. Therefore, better protection was obtained leading to a greater enhancement of the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity of PAL. If the PAL is squeezed out by other molecules, the resulting effect will be /uniFB02 uorescence quenching [56 -58].

In the present study, the Q[7] cavity can accommodate 1.0 equiv. of PAL, forming a 1:1 host-guest inclusion complex. The protection of the Q [7] host leads to an enhancement of the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity of the PAL. When amino acid Phe was added to the host -guest system of Q [7]/PAL, Phe competed to occupy the Q[7] cavity. As we observed in

This paper has explored the binding properties of Q[7] to PAL in aqueous solution by a variety of methods. The experimental results suggest that PAL can be encapsulated into the Q[7] cavity to form a 1:1 hostguest inclusion complex. This inclusion complex PAL@Q[7] displays /uniFB02 uorescence of moderate intensity. Interestingly, upon the addition of Phe, a dramatic quenching of the /uniFB02 uorescence intensity of the inclusion complex is observed. In contrast, the addition of any other natural amino acids does not lead to any /uniFB02 uorescence variation. Thus, herein wehave developed a /uniFB02 uorescence probe based on Q[7] and PAL capable of recognizing the amino acid phenylalanine.
